Article Title: 'Inspired' by mouse watching clips from 'The Matrix', scientists create largest functional map of a brain
Article Text:
Representative Image

Thanks to a mouse watching clips from 'The Matrix', scientists have unveiled the most detailed functional brain map ever, charting connections between 84,000 neurons across 500 million synapses, according to a study published Wednesday in Nature. Using a poppy-seed-sized piece of the mouse‚Äôs brain, researchers traced how neurons communicated through intricate, branch-like fibers, creating a vibrant 3D reconstruction of the neural circuitry. The dataset, now publicly available, offers scientists worldwide a tool to explore brain function and invites curious minds to peek into its complexity.‚ÄúIt definitely inspires a sense of awe, just like looking at pictures of the galaxies,‚Äù Forrest Collman of the Allen Institute for Brain Science in Seattle told The Associated Press. ‚ÄúYou get a sense of how complicated you are. We‚Äôre looking at one tiny part ... of a mouse‚Äôs brain and the beauty and complexity that you can see in these actual neurons and the hundreds of millions of connections between them.‚ÄùThe project, involving over 150 researchers globally, focused on the mouse‚Äôs visual cortex. At Baylor College of Medicine, scientists showed a genetically engineered mouse‚Äîits neurons glowing when active‚Äîvideo snippets of sci-fi films, sports, animations, and nature. A laser-powered microscope captured how cells lit up as the mouse processed the images, the AP reported.At the Allen Institute, that brain fragment was sliced into over 25,000 ultra-thin layers and imaged with electron microscopes, producing nearly 100 million high-resolution pictures. Princeton University researchers then used AI to trace the neural connections, with Collman explaining to the AP that they ‚Äúpaint each of the individual wires a different color so that we can identify them individually.‚ÄùThe mapped wiring, stretching over three miles if laid end-to-end, revealed how visual information flows through the brain. ‚ÄúYou can make a thousand hypotheses about how brain cells might do their job but you can‚Äôt test those hypotheses unless you know ... how are those cells wired together,‚Äù Allen Institute scientist Clay Reid told the AP.The study‚Äôs implications are vast. Researchers likened it to the Human Genome Project, a foundational step toward future treatments. ‚ÄúThe technologies developed by this project will give us our first chance to really identify some kind of abnormal pattern of connectivity that gives rise to a disorder,‚Äù Princeton neuroscientist Sebastian Seung said in a statement to the AP.Harvard neuroscientists Mariela Petkova and Gregor Schuhknecht, unaffiliated with the study, praised it to the AP, saying the work ‚Äúmarks a major leap forwards and offers an invaluable community resource for future discoveries‚Äù in understanding cognition and behavior.Funded by the NIH‚Äôs BRAIN Initiative and IARPA, the MICrONS consortium aims next to map an entire mouse brain , a step toward unraveling disorders like Alzheimer‚Äôs or autism, the AP noted. For now, this neural map‚Äîborn from a mouse and a movie‚Äîstands as a monumental leap in decoding the brain‚Äôs mysteries.
Article Summary: Researchers used a poppy-seed-sized piece of the mouse‚Äôs brain to create a 3D reconstruction of the neural circuitry. The dataset, now publicly available, offers scientists worldwide a tool to explore brain function and invites curious minds to peek into its complexity. Researchers likened it to the Human Genome Project, a foundational step toward future treatments.

Article Title: CEO Andy Jassy on the 'why' question he has to answer everyone even after staying at Amazon for 28-plus years
Article Text:
Amazon's CEO Andy Jassy emphasizes the critical role of persistent questioning, or "WhyQ," in the company's success. He believes this mindset, nurtured through practices like banning PowerPoint and drafting press releases early, helps deconstruct problems and unlock innovation.

Why the ‚ÄúWhyQ‚Äù is important for Amazon CEO Andy Jassy



In Amazon 's relentless culture of innovation, one skill stands above all others according to CEO Andy Jassy ‚Äì the ability to persistently ask "why." This questioning mindset , which Jassy has dubbed "WhyQ" or "YQ," has become a fundamental pillar of Amazon's $2 trillion success story. "Amazon has an unusually high quotient of this WhyQ , and it frames the way we think about everything that we do," Jassy wrote in his recent shareholder letter."Now, with almost 28 years and counting at Amazon, I have to answer those same friends with their own Why question," Jassy wrote in his recent shareholder letter where he emphasized the importance of what he calls "WhyQ" or "YQ" ‚Äî the ability to question everything.The 57-year-old chief executive, who took the helm from founder Jeff Bezos in 2021, believes this questioning mindset has been crucial to both Amazon's $2 trillion success and his personal career trajectory since joining the company in 1997."We ask why, and why not, constantly. It helps us deconstruct problems, get to root causes, understand blockers, and unlock doors that might have previously seemed impenetrable," Jassy explained.This tendency to question started early in his life. "My dad has told me that I was the kind of kid who kept asking why, perhaps to an annoying extent," he admitted in his letter.Jassy believes Amazon's corporate culture intentionally nurtures this questioning mindset through specific practices, including banning PowerPoint presentations in meetings and writing press releases for products before they're even developed."This might bother some regimented folks," he acknowledged. "But, when we're inventing, we accept the process being beautifully imperfect."The chief executive has previously emphasized the importance of attitude in career development, particularly for younger workers. "An embarrassing amount of how well you do, particularly in your twenties, has to do with attitude," Jassy told LinkedIn in an earlier interview.Looking ahead to Amazon's expansion into AI and streaming , Jassy believes this questioning approach will become even more vital: "In the nearly 28 years I've been at Amazon, the biggest difference in the relative growth of companies and individuals has been their aptitude to learn."He argues that maintaining a high "YQ" isn't just nice to have but essential for organizational success : "It needs to be built deeply into your culture and leadership team, and has to be fiercely protected over time if you're lucky enough to be successful."
Article Summary: Amazon's CEO Andy Jassy emphasizes the critical role of persistent questioning, or "WhyQ," in the company's success. He believes this mindset, nurtured through practices like banning PowerPoint and drafting press releases early, helps deconstruct problems and unlock innovation.

Article Title: Infosys' Nandan Nilekani: Indians 'Need not lose sleep' over developing large AI models like China's DeepSeek, as ...
Article Text:
Nandan Nilekani, Infosys Co-founder

Nandan Nilekani's AI warning for 'Every day life' India to be home to 1 million startups by 2035 India is firmly positioned in the global artificial intelligence (AI) race and is now focused on scaling its national AI initiatives, said Nandan Nilekani , co-founder of Infosys and architect of Aadhaar, during the Global Technology Summit on Friday. Nilekani emphasized that while India may not yet have developed large-scale AI models like some other countries, significant progress is already underway."Indians should not worry about not having developed large AI models like some other countries. We should not be losing sleep because somebody has not built any AI models,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe Indian AI mission is active, and now the focus must shift to scaling it up.‚Äù He underscored that the current AI wave marks a major shift from earlier technology revolutions. ‚ÄúFor the first time, we are placing our trust in non-human intelligence. In the past, technology followed predictable rules; now, we‚Äôre expecting machines to make decisions. That‚Äôs a major leap of faith,‚Äù he noted.Despite the excitement around AI, Nilekani warned that integrating the technology into everyday systems won't be straightforward. ‚ÄúAdopting AI is not going to be easy. It requires just as much, if not more, effort than previous technologies,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou have to reengineer workflows in both enterprises and government to make AI truly effective. It demands extensive upgrades, though the core principles still apply.‚ÄùHowever, he believes India‚Äôs digital transformation over the past 15 years gives it a competitive advantage.‚ÄúGiven our current tech infrastructure, the gap between global AI developments and India‚Äôs progress is narrowing rapidly,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúEnterprise AI will be a long journey, and public sector adoption will be even tougher due to structural limitations.‚ÄùNilekani also painted an ambitious picture for India‚Äôs startup landscape. He predicted the country could be home to one million startups by 2035, a dramatic jump from just 2,000 in 2015.‚ÄúFrom 2,000 startups in 2015 to 150,000 today‚Äîwe‚Äôre in the midst of a virtuous cycle,‚Äù he explained. ‚ÄúStartups solve real-world problems, scale up, go public, and spark the creation of more startups. This cycle is accelerating innovation across sectors like climate, energy, and space.‚ÄùHe celebrated India‚Äôs growing private innovation in sectors traditionally led by the state, highlighting the country‚Äôs ‚Äúfabulous‚Äù space narrative as an example.Nilekani also revisited some milestones in India‚Äôs digital public infrastructure journey. These include: Aadhaar reaching 1 billion people; UPI launch, Reliance Jio disrupting the telecom sector, demonetisation reshaping financial behavior and BHIM app launch.‚ÄúThese were not overnight developments. They were years in the making,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou need patience to lay the foundation. Once it's in place, transformation can happen rapidly‚Äîand now, we‚Äôre more prepared than ever.‚Äù
Article Summary: Infosys co-founder Nandan Nilekani spoke at the Global Technology Summit. He said India is firmly positioned in the global artificial intelligence (AI) race. He predicted the country could be home to one million startups by 2035.

Article Title: Bryan Johnson says he has quit a drug popular in anti-ageing circles after it actually accelerated his aging process
Article Text:
(Pic courtesy: Youtube/ Bryan johnson)

The drug that Bryan Johnson says accelerated his aging process

Anti-aging influencer Bryan Johnson , known for his extreme $2 million annual health regimen aimed at reversing aging, has publicly admitted that a key component of his protocol, the drug Rapamycin, may have been detrimental to his health. In a recent YouTube video, the 46-year-old biohacker revealed he experienced several negative side effects after five years of carefully adjusting his Rapamycin dosage.The immunosuppressant, initially developed for organ transplant recipients, gained popularity in anti-aging circles due to studies suggesting it could extend lifespan by targeting the mTOR pathway. Johnson was inspired by research showing increased lifespan in mice and improved health outcomes in a human trial.However, instead of the anticipated rejuvenation, Johnson suffered from mouth ulcers, slow-healing wounds, elevated cholesterol, and blood glucose spikes. Most concerning was a sustained increase in his resting heart rate, a crucial metric for his recovery and sleep quality. These physiological changes prompted him to discontinue the drug.Adding to his concerns, a recent Yale University study challenged the purported anti-aging benefits of Rapamycin, suggesting it might actually accelerate biological aging by negatively impacting epigenetic markers.Despite the setback, Johnson stated that stopping Rapamycin was a "reset," not a surrender, emphasizing the importance of sharing both successes and failures in the pursuit of understanding how to slow aging. He acknowledged the irony of a central element of his meticulously planned regimen potentially causing harm, stating, "To those of you laughing at home, I‚Äôm laughing with you." Johnson maintains that his approach is part of a scientific exploration, accepting the risks involved in trying to identify interventions that genuinely impact the aging process.
Article Summary: Bryan Johnson, known for his extreme $2 million annual health regimen aimed at reversing aging, has publicly admitted that a key component of his protocol, the drug Rapamycin, may have been detrimental to his health. Johnson suffered from mouth ulcers, slow-healing wounds, elevated cholesterol, and blood glucose spikes.

Article Title: Apple, tech sector get relief: Smartphones, laptops excluded and other key electronics exempted from Trump Tariffs
Article Text:
Phones, PCs, chips exempted from Trump‚Äôs reciprocal tariffs

The US Customs and Border Protection has released new guidelines that specify certain technology devices and components will be exempt from reciprocal tariffs initiated by US President Donald Trump . The latest notice comes as previous action had raised significant concerns for technology companies, most notably Apple , which manufactures the majority of its iPhones and other products within China.According to a report by CNBC, the information was disseminated late Friday (April 11) evening. The latest guidance is a direct response to President Trump's earlier decision to impose a 145% tariff on products originating from China.The newly-issued tariff guidance identifies a range of electronics that will receive exclusions. This list includes laptops, semiconductors, solar cells, flat panel television displays, flash drives, memory cards, and solid-state drives, all of which are used for data storage.Notably, these products may be subject to future duties. These exemptions represent a somewhat favourable outcome for technology companies such as Apple. As per data from Evercore ISI, Apple manufactures over 80% of its products in China, including 80% of iPads and more than half of its Mac computers.Recently, Apple experienced a loss of over $640 billion in market value in the period following President Trump's tariff announcement.Moreover, Apple reportedly chartered multiple cargo flights to ship an estimated 1.5 million iPhones, weighing approximately 600 tons, from India to the US. This move aimed at ramping up inventory in the home country to mitigate the potential impact of tariffs previously threatened by Trump.
Article Summary: US Customs and Border Protection has released new guidelines that specify certain technology devices and components will be exempt from reciprocal tariffs initiated by US President Donald Trump. This list includes laptops, semiconductors, solar cells, flat panel television displays, flash drives, memory cards, and solid-state drives.

Article Title: Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg adds two more people to Meta board, one of them has served as deputy national security adviser to Donald Trump
Article Text:
Who are Patrick Collison and Dina Powell McCormick

Facebook parent company Meta has expanded its board with tech and finance leaders by electing Patrick Collison and Dina Powell McCormick , respectively. Their appointments take effect on April 15. Company founder and CEO, Mark Zuckerberg , highlighted the valuable contributions the new board members will bring.‚ÄúPatrick and Dina bring a lot of experience supporting businesses and entrepreneurs to our board,‚Äù Zuckerberg said on the announcement.‚ÄúPatrick is deeply committed to expanding economic opportunity, and Dina has a long career advocating for economic development and supporting entrepreneurs. Their perspective will be extremely valuable to businesses that rely on our services to grow,‚Äù he added.Patrick Collison is the co-founder and CEO of Stripe, a technology company specialising in programmable financial services, expressed his enthusiasm for joining Meta's board.‚ÄúBetween WhatsApp, Instagram and Facebook, Meta is one of the internet‚Äôs most important platforms for businesses,‚Äù Collison said on the appointment.‚ÄúI look forward to helping them navigate the abundant opportunities of the coming years,‚Äù he added.Collison, who founded Stripe with his brother John Collison in 2010, is also a co-founder of the Arc Institute, a biomedical research institution focused on pioneering new models for basic research.Meanwhile, Dina Powell McCormick, currently vice chair, president and head of global client services at BDT & MSD Partners, also shared her excitement about her new role. McCormick brings over 25 years of experience at the highest levels of finance and US government.‚ÄúI‚Äôm excited to bring my experience in finance, government and economic development to support the people and entrepreneurs who use Meta‚Äôs services,‚Äù she said.Her career includes 16 years in senior leadership positions at Goldman Sachs, where she served on the management committee, led the firm's Global Sovereign investment banking business, and spearheaded major economic development initiatives such as 10,000 Women, 10,000 Small Businesses, and One Million Black Women.Additionally, McCormick has served two US presidents, holding positions as Deputy National Security Advisor to President Donald J. Trump and Assistant to the President for Presidential Personnel and Senior White House Advisor. Under President George W. Bush, she served as Assistant Secretary of State for Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice.McCormick is also a New York Times best-selling author, having co-written "Who Believed in You, the Power of Transformative Mentorship" with her husband, United States Senator from Pennsylvania David McCormick.
Article Summary: Facebook parent company Meta has expanded its board with tech and finance leaders by electing Patrick Collison and Dina Powell McCormick. Their appointments take effect on April 15. Company founder and CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, highlighted the valuable contributions the new board members will bring.

Article Title: Donald Trump just gave Samsung a 'huge problem' and it is called Vietnam
Article Text:
Vietnam's role in Samsung's operations

Impact on Samsung and Vietnam

US President Donald Trump's latest tariff hikes have created a significant challenge for Samsung Electronics, with Vietnam emerging as a focal point of the escalating trade tensions. The new tariffs, which raise duties on Vietnamese exports to the US to 46%, threaten to disrupt Samsung's global supply chain and its reliance on Vietnam as a manufacturing hub.Vietnam has been a cornerstone of Samsung's manufacturing strategy since the South Korean tech giant entered the country in 1989. The company produces 60% of its global smartphone output in Vietnam, with many of these devices destined for the US, where Samsung is the second-largest smartphone vendor. Vietnam's $120 billion trade surplus with the US has now placed it squarely in the crosshairs of Trump's tariff policies.The tariff hike has exposed vulnerabilities in Vietnam's export-driven economy and Samsung's heavy reliance on the country. While Vietnam has secured a temporary reprieve with a 90-day pause on the full tariff implementation, the uncertainty has already prompted Samsung and its suppliers to explore alternative production strategies. Options include increasing output in India or South Korea, though these shifts would be costly and time-consuming.The tariffs not only jeopardize Samsung's operations but also highlight the risks of over-reliance on a single manufacturing base. Vietnam, which has benefited from companies diversifying away from China, now faces challenges such as rising labor costs, power supply issues, and the loss of earlier tax incentives.
Article Summary: Vietnam has been a cornerstone of Samsung's manufacturing strategy since 1989. Samsung produces 60% of its global smartphone output in Vietnam, with many of these devices destined for the US. Vietnam's $120 billion trade surplus with the US has now placed it squarely in the crosshairs of Trump's tariff policies.

NPCI has not issued an update.UPI experienced yet another service outage, resulting in thousands of users reporting their inability to make payments and execute fund transfers. Downdetector reported a peak of over 2,200 user complaints concerning UPI services, primarily related to failed payment transactions and fund transfers.The disruption has affected a broad range of major payment platforms, including Google Pay , PhonePe , and Paytm, as well as various banking applications. Notably, the TOI Tech team's attempts to make payments and transfer funds were also unsuccessful.Downdetector's data further indicated reports of service disruptions affecting both State Bank of India (SBI), ICICI and HDFC as well as Google Pay, demonstrating the expanded reach of the technical difficulties.The National Payments Corporation of India (NPCI), the entity responsible for the operation of the UPI network, has acknowledged the issue and said that it is working to resolve the disruption."NPCI is currently facing intermittent technical issues, leading to partial UPI transaction declines. NPCI attributed these issues to an ‚Äúintermittent technical issue.‚ÄùAt that time, NPCI acknowledged the disruption and subsequently reported that the system had been restored to normal operation. Article Summary: Third UPI disruption in about three weeks. Downdetector reports a significant decrease in complaints, with only 225 at the time of writing. The disruption has affected a broad range of major payment platforms, including Google Pay and PhonePe.
